title: Socio-Spatial Properties of Online Location-Based Social Networks

author: Salvatore Scellato, Computer Laboratory, University of Cambridge

As we all think we all, as we all know, I think in the last couple of years, location based social networks have experienced the increasing levels of popularity.

And this is basically telling us that we can actually use the these services to get data to get insight into special social behavior, because for the first time we not only have access to the social network among these users, but we also have access to where these people go and where these people live.
So what we can do is, as Facebook has done in these figures in this image, they can actually put people on a map and they can stretch all their social ties across space.

And this availability of social and geographic data together opens up new research opportunities and in order to understand how we can blend together space and social behavior, we need to make use of some tools that were developed in another field which is the field of spatial networks.
What is a special network?
Well, it's any network where the nodes are embedded in a metric space, so it's possible to define a metric distance between them.

There are many examples of social networks for recent Asportation systems, a network of flights between airports, electric power grids, or as we see in this figure on Urban Rd network of the all the roads in Barcelona.
So in a special network there is indeed this metric distance which is directly influencing the network structure that we see.
Because the distance is imposing higher costs on connection that are between distant nodes.
Think about a special network between airports.
If there is a flight between very too far away, airports that fly is much more expensive, so there will be less long range flights and more short range flight.

However, it's not really clear how magic distance is influencing social ties, because it's not really clear whether there is such a cost involved in maintaining a social friendship across the distance.
Even in sociology there are different schools of thought.
One popular assumption is that most individuals tries to minimize their efforts to maintain a friendship.
So what they do is they tend to interact more with their special neighbors because it's less expensive to interact over short range distances.

However, there are other researchers that have put forward another another positive, which is the one of the death of distance, which was popularized by Frances Cairncross and the idea here is that the connection costs are not as important in social networks are as in other special networks, and this is because with online communication tools with long distance travel, which is now very cheap, distance is now dead.
The world appears the shrinking as people interact and communicate with each other, regardless of the distances that separates them.

However, in the last years what we have seen is we are seeing some initial results on one fundamental special property of social networks, which is the probability that two individuals that are at distance D are friends.

So the first work was done in 2005 on the live Journal blogging community, and what there is the researchers have found is that this probability, the probability that two bloggers at distance D are friends, is proportional to D to the minus one plus a certain background probability that basically kicks in only at very high very long distances.
So there seems to be an effective distance, because if you're close to another Blogger you are more likely to become two ads that Blogger as.
